title: Detroit Lions blow massive opportunity vs. Green Bay Packers at Lambeau. Blame them.
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: Week 6 had some stunning results but none bigger than the Cowboys loss to the winless New York Jets. As Trysta Krick details, they do have one saving grace. USA TODAY

GREEN BAY, Wis. — The Detroit Lions blew it.

The Lions had a chance to take over first place in the NFC North on Monday night.

They had an opportunity to make a major statement against the Green Bay Packers.

But they let it slip away.

Because they blew a lead and wasted scoring opportunities, getting into the red zone three times, but walking away with just one touchdown. So that’s on the Lions.

You can’t do that against the Packers and expect to win. Not at Lambeau Field. And the Lions lost, 23-22.

As the Lions were melting down the stretch, it looked so familiar, just like the game against Kansas City, when they once again jumped out to a lead and then let it slip away.

This time it was Aaron Rodgers, leading the Packers downfield in the final minutes. Getting free on runs. Making clutch throws.

But the Lions didn’t blow this game by themselves. The refs made several questionable calls that cost them. Trey Flowers was called for two penalties — illegal use of hands to the face mask — and both led to Green Bay touchdowns.

But he appeared to grab the shoulder pads, not the face mask.

The final call gave the Packers all they needed on their game-winning drive: A 23-yard field goal as time expired.

Packers safety Adrian Amos breaks up a pass intended for Lions running back Kerryon Johnson. (Photo: Tannen Maury, EPA-EFE/REX)

Mistakes and blown opportunities

The Lions will look back at several mistakes and blown opportunities.

They kicked way too many field goals and wasted several chances. T.J. Hockenson couldn’t hang onto a touchdown pass and they had to settle for a field goal.

They also made mistakes on special teams. First, Sam Martin kicked the ball out of bounds, giving the Packers a short field. When the Packers lined up for a field goal, the Lions lined up with 12 men on the field. That’s just boneheaded. The kind of thing that lets a team back into a game.

Two plays later, Jamaal Williams was scampering into the end zone on a touchdown.

In the third quarter, the Lions wasted another opportunity, after Dee Virgin caused a fumble on a punt.

The Lions advanced inside the Packers 25-yard line and had to settle for a field goal. Technically, it wasn’t inside the red zone. But it was another blown opportunity, wasting a short field.

The refs

I hate mentioning the refs in a story, but this was just crazy.

One of the most questionable calls came in the fourth quarter. Flowers was flagged for an illegal use of hands, which was essentially a turnover, giving the Packers an extra possession. And it seemed to be a horrible call. That gave the Packers a first down and another chance.

Three plays later, Rogers hit Allen Lazard on a tremendous, 35-yard touchdown

Final: Packers 23, Lions 22.



Lions blow a 13-point lead, settle for 5 field goals and have multiple blown calls go against them but, on the bright side, in 5 billion years the sun will swell into a red giant, vaporize the Earth and obliterate all evidence of this game happening — Detroit Free Press (@freep) October 15, 2019

A hot start

The Lions jumped out to a 10-0 lead, thanks to an aggressive, gunslinger approach on offense and a defense that was making plays.

The Packers’ first drive fizzled when, if you are a Packers fan, you saw Geronimo Allison drop a certain first down. But if you are a Lions fan, you saw Justin Coleman knock it loose. He was fantastic.

On another drive, the Lions’ A’Shawn Robinson came off a block and knocked the ball away from Aaron Jones, killing a Green Bay drive.

But they wasted those plays.

They wasted this game.

description: You can blame the refs for the Detroit Lions' loss to the Green Bay Packers on Monday night. But blame the Lions, too.
